query: What methods are available to control disease and sea lice in Atlantic salmon farms?
relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents identifies several methods: using natural control agents such as cleaner wrasse shows mixed effects on sea lice; corkwing and goldsinny wrasse were as effective as chemical treatments in one controlled study, while rockcook wrasse were ineffective in a replicated, controlled study (738). Dietary and immune-based approaches include probiotics that increased survival after exposure to four bacterial pathogens, and diets with 28% plant protein that reduced lice infections by 28% with an additional 28% reduction when beta-glucans were added; mannan oligosaccharides improved gut function by preventing soybean-induced enteritis (732). Operational fallowing reduced lice numbers in one Scottish study, though an Australian study found no difference in Amoebic Gill Disease mortality (1026). Selective breeding for disease resistance increased survival against infectious pancreatic necrosis (735). Aerobic training increased survival against infectious pancreatic necrosis, with interval training outperforming continuous training (740). Freshwater bathing to manage amoebic gill disease showed mixed results, with one study reporting reduced amoebae for up to 10 days and another finding no difference (739).

  "action_title": "Use of probiotics and immunostimulants",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
 

One replicated study in Scotland found increased survival in salmon fed a probiotic before exposure to four different disease-causing bacteria over a 28 day period compared with controls.
A replicated, controlled study in Norway found the number of salmon infected with lice was reduced by 28% when fed a diet composed of fish meal and 28% plant-based protein. Adding beta-glucans to the diet decreased lice infection levels by a further 28% compared with controls.
The same study found the addition of mannan oligosaccharides improved gut function by preventing the development of soybean-induced enteritis compared with controls."
}

query: How do plant-based and bacterial protein alternatives to fish meal compare in terms of their effect on Atlantic salmon growth rates in Norway?
relevant_summary: Bacterial protein: In Norway, two replicated, controlled studies found similar growth rates when up to 25% of fish meal was replaced with bacterial protein, while a 50% replacement reduced growth; another replicated, controlled study in Norway reported higher growth at 18% and 36% bacterial protein compared to the control or a 4.5% inclusion (918). Plant-based protein: Across studies that included Norway, several replicated/controlled studies found decreased growth rates with plant-based protein, while other replicated/controlled studies from Norway reported similar growth rates to fish meal diets (924).

tools_called.args: {"query_string": "Atlantic salmon Norway growth rates plant-based bacterial protein alternatives to fish meal", "k": 3, "offset": 0}
{"action_id":"918"}
{"action_id":"924"}
tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "924",
  "action_title": "Use an alternative protein source: plant-based",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Six studies (four replicated, controlled) in Norway, Scotland and the USA found that inclusion of plant-based proteins within feed led to decreased growth rates in salmon. Three replicated and/or controlled studies from Norway, Canada and Scotland found similar growth rates in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
Four replicated, controlled studies (three randomised) from Norway and Scotland found reduced final body weights in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal-based diets. Two controlled studies (one replicated) from Norway found similar final body weights in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
Two replicated, controlled studies (one randomised) from Norway found lowered levels of feeding efficiency, whereas a replicated study in Norway found increased levels of feeding efficiency in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal diets. Two replicated studies (one controlled) in Canada and Scotland study found similar levels of feeding efficiency across both diet types.
Digestibility of feed components by salmon was found to be lower in two replicated, controlled studies when the diets contained plant proteins compared to fish meal. Similar levels of digestibility across both diet types were identified by two randomised, replicated, controlled studies in Scotland and Norway. 
Two of the studies found that survival rates and appetite were not affected by plant- or fish meal-based protein diets. However morphology of the distal intestine was altered in two randomised, replicated, controlled studies where salmon were fed diets containing plant-based proteins. Condition of the salmon was increased in plant-based protein diets in one randomised, replicated, controlled study but reduced in two other replicated studies."
}

query: Which interventions appear most effective for increasing the survival rates of farmed salmon exposed to disease?
relevant_summary: Evidence indicates higher survival of farmed salmon after disease exposure with: (1) vaccination, which increased survival in controlled studies against Aeromonas salmonicida spp. achromogenes and Yersinia ruckeri in Iceland and Norway, marine flexibacteriosis and bacterial kidney disease in Australia and Canada, and infectious salmon anaemia in Norway [733]; (2) aerobic training, where a randomized, replicated, controlled study in Norway found higher survival after exposure to infectious pancreatic necrosis, with interval training outperforming continuous training [740]; and (3) selective breeding for resistance, where a replicated, controlled study in Norway showed higher survival in families bred for high resistance to infectious pancreatic necrosis compared to low-resistance families [735]. Additional management shows limited or mixed links to survival: fallowing reduced lice in Scotland but did not change mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in Australia [1026]; freshwater bathing showed mixed effects on amoebae levels on gills in Australian studies, without demonstrated survival benefits [739].

Two controlled studies in Australia and Canadia reported higher survival in salmon infected with marine flexibacteriosis and bacterial kidney disease, post vaccination.

query: What are the documented effects of using plant-based proteins in salmon feed in aquaculture operations in Norway and Scotland?
relevant_summary: Across studies conducted in Norway and Scotland, plant-based protein inclusion in salmon feed has been associated with decreased growth rates in some trials, while other trials reported similar growth rates to fish-meal diets [924]. Several replicated, controlled studies in Norway and Scotland reported reduced final body weights with plant-based protein diets, though some Norway-based studies found similar final weights to fish-meal diets [924]. Feeding efficiency outcomes were mixed: some Norway studies found lowered efficiency, one Norway study found increased efficiency, and studies including Scotland reported similar efficiency between plant-based and fish-meal diets [924]. Randomised, replicated, controlled studies in Scotland and Norway reported similar digestibility between plant-based and fish-meal protein diets [924].

query: What are the non-chemical alternatives for controlling sea lice on salmon farms?
relevant_summary:
- Use natural control agents (cleaner wrasse): Two studies in Ireland reported mixed effects; one controlled study found corkwing and goldskinny cleaner wrasse were as effective as chemical treatments at controlling lice infestation, while one replicated, controlled study found rockcook cleaner wrasse were ineffective at preventing lice outbreaks [738].
- Alter lighting: A replicated, controlled study in Norway reported lower numbers of lice on salmon kept in low intensity artificial light or natural lighting, with more intense artificial light associated with higher lice numbers [741].
- Establish fallowing: A study in Scotland recorded lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages using a fallowing system [1026].

query: How do krill, yeast, and animal protein alternatives to fishmeal compare in their effect on Atlantic salmon growth?
relevant_summary:
- Krill meal: Two replicated studies in Norway found similar final weight gain between salmon fed fishmeal and those fed a krill meal substitute; when krill were de-shelled, growth rates were closer to salmon fed fishmeal than when krill were left whole (Action 916).
- Yeast: One replicated, controlled experiment in Norway found no differences in weight between Atlantic salmon fed diets containing the yeast Yarrowia lipolytica and a control diet containing fishmeal (Action 920).
- Animal protein alternatives: One controlled, randomised, replicated study in Scotland showed that fish fed a fishmeal diet weighed more than fish fed diets with alternative proteins (Action 922).

query: What is the evidence from studies in Norway for using alternative feed components in Atlantic salmon diets?
relevant_summary: In Norway, a replicated, controlled experiment found no difference in weight when Atlantic salmon were fed Yarrowia lipolytica yeast compared to a fishmeal control [920]. For plant-based proteins, studies from Norway and Scotland reported reduced final body weights in some trials, while two controlled studies from Norway found similar final body weights; feeding efficiency in Norway was lower in two replicated, controlled studies (one randomised) but higher in one replicated study; digestibility was similar in randomised, replicated, controlled studies conducted in Scotland and Norway [924]. For plant-based oils, replicated studies in Norway found similar growth rates to fish oil, with one Norwegian study reporting higher growth on vegetable oil; two Norwegian studies found similar final body weights; Norwegian work also reported that broodstock fecundity, egg weights, fertility, and fry development were unaffected by oil source, that vegetable oil diets produced higher liver lipid and lower plasma lipoprotein than fish oil, and that flesh quality metrics (gaping, texture, liquid holding) were similar though pigment concentration was lower; studies in Norway and Scotland found fillet fatty acid profiles reflected dietary oil source [926]. Two replicated studies in Norway substituting krill meal for fish meal found similar final weight gain; de-shelled krill produced growth closer to fish meal, feed conversion ratios were similar, and hindgut aerobic bacterial numbers were higher with different flora composition [916]. Two replicated Norwegian studies reducing fish meal levels (low, medium, high) reported similar final weights [915]. Three controlled, replicated (two randomised) studies in Norway found no difference in growth rate when salmon were fed GM vs. non-GM soybeans, and one randomised, replicated, controlled Norwegian study found no histological differences [928]. A controlled, replicated study in Norway reported no difference in weight gain with taurine supplementation [930].

query: What are the effects of altering the physical environment of salmon cages, such as their size or lighting, on salmon health in aquaculture?

A replicated, controlled study in Norway reported fewer sea lice on salmon kept under low-intensity artificial lighting or natural light, and that higher-intensity artificial lighting was associated with higher lice numbers (741).

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Four studies evaluated the effects of using low intensity lighting on reptile populations. Three studies were in the USA1-3 and one was in Malaysia4.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (4 STUDIES)

Behaviour change (4 studies): One replicated, controlled study in the USA1 found that reducing the intensity of light sources did not improve loggerhead turtle hatchling seaward orientation. query: Which dietary alternatives or supplements to traditional fish meal have been shown to have no negative impact on Atlantic salmon growth or weight?
relevant_summary:
- Dietary supplements: A controlled, replicated study in Australia found no difference in weight gain with phytase and phosphate supplementation, and a controlled, replicated study in Norway found no difference in weight gain with taurine supplementation; another Australian study reported greater final weights with phytase supplementation [930].
- Krill meal as an alternative protein: Two replicated studies in Norway found similar final weight gain between salmon fed fish meal only and those fed a krill meal substitute; de-shelling krill brought growth rates closer to fish-meal-fed fish [916].
- Plant-based protein as an alternative: Three replicated and/or controlled studies from Norway, Canada and Scotland found similar growth rates in salmon fed plant-based and fish meal diets, and two controlled studies from Norway found similar final body weights between plant-based and fish meal diets [924].
- Bacterial protein as an alternative: Two replicated, controlled studies in Norway found similar growth rates when up to 25% of fish meal was replaced with bacterial protein; another replicated, controlled study reported higher growth at 18% and 36% bacterial protein inclusion [918].
- Reduced fish meal inclusion: Two replicated studies in Norway found similar final weights among salmon fed diets with low, medium, or high levels of fish meal [915].

  "action_title": "Use an alternative protein source: plant-based",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Six studies (four replicated, controlled) in Norway, Scotland and the USA found that inclusion of plant-based proteins within feed led to decreased growth rates in salmon. Three replicated and/or controlled studies from Norway, Canada and Scotland found similar growth rates in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
Four replicated, controlled studies (three randomised) from Norway and Scotland found reduced final body weights in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal-based diets. Two controlled studies (one replicated) from Norway found similar final body weights in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
Two replicated, controlled studies (one randomised) from Norway found lowered levels of feeding efficiency, whereas a replicated study in Norway found increased levels of feeding efficiency in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal diets. Two replicated studies (one controlled) in Canada and Scotland study found similar levels of feeding efficiency across both diet types.
Digestibility of feed components by salmon was found to be lower in two replicated, controlled studies when the diets contained plant proteins compared to fish meal. Similar levels of digestibility across both diet types were identified by two randomised, replicated, controlled studies in Scotland and Norway. 
Two of the studies found that survival rates and appetite were not affected by plant- or fish meal-based protein diets. However morphology of the distal intestine was altered in two randomised, replicated, controlled studies where salmon were fed diets containing plant-based proteins. Condition of the salmon was increased in plant-based protein diets in one randomised, replicated, controlled study but reduced in two other replicated studies."
}

query: What is the evidence that integrated aquaculture systems or constructing artificial reefs can mitigate the environmental impacts of salmon farms?
relevant_summary: Two controlled studies on artificial reefs near aquaculture sites reported no detectable differences compared to sites without aquaculture: one Mediterranean study found similar invertebrate community composition on an artificial reef under aquaculture cages versus reefs away from cages, and one Gulf of Aqaba study found similar invertebrate biomass on an artificial reef at an aquaculture site versus a site without cages [2260]. For proposed mitigation approaches related to integrated aquaculture systems and biofiltration, evidence gaps were identified: no studies were found evaluating the effects of using species from multiple trophic levels in aquaculture systems [2195], locating artificial reefs near aquaculture to act explicitly as biofilters [2196], locating aquaculture systems in vegetated areas [2189], or establishing aquaculture specifically to extract nutrients from run-offs [2200].

query: What are the observed effects on salmon growth and flesh quality when replacing fish oil with plant-based or other animal-based oils in their diet?
relevant_summary: Across replicated studies in Norway and Scotland, replacing fish oil with vegetable (plant-based) oils produced: (1) growth outcomes that were similar between fish oil and vegetable oil diets in three studies, with one study reporting higher growth on vegetable oil, and one replicated, controlled study showing growth was both lower and higher on vegetable oil depending on family genetics [926]; (2) similar average final body weights between fish fed fish oil and vegetable oil diets in two studies [926]; (3) flesh fatty acid profiles that reflected the dietary oil source in multiple studies [926]; (4) lower concentrations of dioxins and polychlorinated biphenyls in flesh when fish were fed vegetable oil-based diets compared to fish oil diets in a replicated, controlled study [926]; (5) similar gaping, texture, and liquid-holding capacity in fresh, frozen, and smoked flesh between diets, while pigment concentration was lower with vegetable oil diets [926]; (6) higher liver lipid and lower plasma lipoprotein in salmon fed vegetable oil diets compared to fish oil diets in one replicated study [926]; and (7) one replicated, controlled study reporting high levels of n-3 highly unsaturated fatty acids compared to diets containing rapeseed oil [926]. No specific action documents were found detailing effects of replacing fish oil with other animal-based oils beyond these plant-based oil findings.

query: What are the comparative effects on Atlantic salmon weight when substituting fishmeal with krill, yeast, or other animal-based proteins?
relevant_summary: Two replicated studies in Norway reported similar final weight gain between Atlantic salmon fed fishmeal and those fed a krill meal substitute; when krill were de-shelled, growth rates were closer to salmon fed fishmeal than when krill were left whole [916]. One replicated, controlled experiment in Norway found no differences in weight between salmon fed the yeast Yarrowia lipolytica and a control diet containing fishmeal [920]. One controlled, randomised, replicated study from Scotland showed that fish fed a fishmeal diet weighed more than fish fed diets with alternative proteins [922].

query: What is the evidence from studies in Norway regarding the effectiveness of non-dietary interventions for improving farmed Atlantic salmon health and survival?
relevant_summary: In Norway, controlled studies reported that vaccinating Atlantic salmon improved outcomes: one controlled study found higher survival in vaccinated fish following exposure to Yersinia ruckeri compared with unvaccinated controls [733], and two controlled studies reported similar results for fish vaccinated against infectious salmon anaemia [733]. A replicated, controlled study in Norway found that altering lighting reduced lice loads, with low-intensity artificial or natural lighting associated with fewer lice, while higher-intensity artificial lighting increased lice numbers [741].

query: What actions are available to manage the waste products, such as excess nutrients and sludge, from salmon aquaculture operations?
relevant_summary:
- Integrated aquaculture systems co-culturing extractive species alongside salmon farms can assimilate wastes: studies reported blue mussels absorbing waste from a salmon farm, greater scallop growth next to fish farms, and enhanced algal growth adjacent to fish farms; one study found no evidence that oysters and mussels fed on fish farm waste (932). 
- Fallowing salmon cages to reduce pollution has been trialed; sediment community structure under Atlantic salmon cages became more similar to non‑impacted sites over two fallowing cycles (1027). 
- Establishing aquaculture specifically to extract nutrients from run‑offs is identified as an action, though the evidence base for effects on marine or freshwater mammals has not been established (2883, 3587). 
- Using species from more than one trophic level in aquaculture (e.g., IMTA approaches) is identified as an action, though effects on subtidal benthic invertebrates have not yet been evaluated (2195). 
- Other bioremediation methods in aquaculture are identified as potential actions, but effects on subtidal benthic invertebrates have not yet been evaluated (2197). 
- Modifying aquaculture practices in the watershed to reduce pollution is listed as an action, but no studies were found evaluating effects on marsh or swamp vegetation (3172).

query: What is the evidence from Australian studies on the effectiveness of different husbandry practices for managing Amoebic Gill Disease in farmed salmon?
relevant_summary: Australian studies report mixed effects of freshwater bathing on amoebic gill disease: one study found reduced numbers of amoebae on salmon gills persisting for up to 10 days after bathing, while one replicated, controlled study found similar levels of amoebae in treated and untreated salmon [739]. A replicated study in Australia recorded lower levels of amoebic gill disease in salmon kept in larger cages compared to smaller cages [742]. One study in Australia found no difference in mortality from amoebic gill disease in cages where a fallowing system had been used [1026].

query: Beyond growth rates, what other biological effects have been observed in salmon fed diets with krill or plant-based proteins instead of fish meal?
relevant_summary: Plant-based proteins: feeding efficiency was lowered in two replicated, controlled studies, increased in one replicated study, and similar in two replicated studies (ID: 924). Digestibility of feed components was lower in two replicated, controlled studies, with similar digestibility reported in two randomised, replicated, controlled studies (ID: 924). Survival rates and appetite were not affected in two studies (ID: 924). Morphology of the distal intestine was altered in two randomised, replicated, controlled studies (ID: 924). Condition increased in one randomised, replicated, controlled study but was reduced in two other replicated studies (ID: 924). Krill meal: feed conversion ratios were similar to fish meal (ID: 916). In salmon fed fish meal and krill meal, the number of aerobic bacteria in the hindgut was higher and the composition of the bacterial flora was different (ID: 916).

  "action_title": "Use an alternative protein source: plant-based",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Six studies (four replicated, controlled) in Norway, Scotland and the USA found that inclusion of plant-based proteins within feed led to decreased growth rates in salmon. Three replicated and/or controlled studies from Norway, Canada and Scotland found similar growth rates in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
Four replicated, controlled studies (three randomised) from Norway and Scotland found reduced final body weights in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal-based diets. Two controlled studies (one replicated) from Norway found similar final body weights in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
Two replicated, controlled studies (one randomised) from Norway found lowered levels of feeding efficiency, whereas a replicated study in Norway found increased levels of feeding efficiency in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal diets. Two replicated studies (one controlled) in Canada and Scotland study found similar levels of feeding efficiency across both diet types.
Digestibility of feed components by salmon was found to be lower in two replicated, controlled studies when the diets contained plant proteins compared to fish meal. Similar levels of digestibility across both diet types were identified by two randomised, replicated, controlled studies in Scotland and Norway. 
Two of the studies found that survival rates and appetite were not affected by plant- or fish meal-based protein diets. However morphology of the distal intestine was altered in two randomised, replicated, controlled studies where salmon were fed diets containing plant-based proteins. Condition of the salmon was increased in plant-based protein diets in one randomised, replicated, controlled study but reduced in two other replicated studies."
}

query: What factors influence the success of non-pesticide methods for controlling sea lice on salmon farms?
relevant_summary: Evidence indicates that outcomes depend on the specific method and implementation: the effectiveness of cleaner wrasse varies by species, with one controlled study finding corkwing and goldsinny wrasse as effective as chemical treatments while another found rockcook wrasse ineffective at preventing outbreaks [738]. Light regime matters, with lower lice counts under natural or low‑intensity artificial light, and higher counts as artificial light intensity increases [741]. Farm management through fallowing has been associated with lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in at least one study [1026]. Nutritional and immunostimulant strategies can reduce lice infection levels, including a diet with 28% plant-based protein and additional reductions when beta‑glucans are added, compared with controls [732].

query: In Norway, how do different plant-based feed alternatives, such as vegetable oils versus plant proteins, affect salmon growth and body composition?
relevant_summary: Across studies that included Norway, plant-protein diets sometimes reduced growth rates compared to fish meal, though some studies reported similar growth rates (924). Reduced final body weights were reported in replicated, controlled studies conducted in Norway and Scotland, while two Norwegian studies found similar final weights between plant-protein and fish-meal diets (924). In Norway, feeding efficiency responses to plant proteins were mixed, with two replicated, controlled studies showing lower efficiency and one replicated study showing higher efficiency compared to fish-meal diets; some other studies reported similar efficiency (924). For vegetable oils in Norway, multiple replicated studies found growth rates similar to fish-oil diets, one study found higher growth on vegetable oils, and one controlled study showed family-dependent higher or lower growth on vegetable oils (926). Norwegian studies reported similar average final body weights between fish-oil and vegetable-oil diets (926). Body composition responses with vegetable oils included salmon flesh fatty-acid profiles reflecting dietary oil source in Norway and Scotland, higher liver lipid and lower plasma lipoprotein on vegetable-oil diets in a Norwegian study, and lower flesh pigment concentration with vegetable oils alongside similar gaping, texture, and liquid-holding capacity in Norwegian product-quality tests (926).

query: What are the documented effects, both positive and negative, of replacing fish meal with plant-based proteins in Atlantic salmon diets?
relevant_summary: Across studies, replacing fish meal with plant-based proteins in Atlantic salmon diets was associated with decreased growth rates in six studies, while three studies found similar growth to fish meal diets (924). Four studies reported reduced final body weight with plant-based protein diets, whereas two found similar final body weight to fish meal diets (924). Feeding efficiency was lowered in two studies, increased in one, and similar in two others when using plant-based proteins (924). Digestibility of feed components was lower in two studies with plant proteins, but similar in two other studies (924). Two studies reported no effect on survival or appetite (924). Distal intestine morphology was altered in two studies with plant-based proteins (924). Condition increased in one study but was reduced in two others with plant-based protein diets (924). Additionally, two replicated studies found similar final weights across diets containing low, medium, or high levels of fish meal (915).

Six studies (four replicated, controlled) in Norway, Scotland and the USA found that inclusion of plant-based proteins within feed led to decreased growth rates in salmon. Similar levels of digestibility across both diet types were identified by two randomised, replicated, controlled studies in Scotland and Norway. 
Two of the studies found that survival rates and appetite were not affected by plant- or fish meal-based protein diets. However morphology of the distal intestine was altered in two randomised, replicated, controlled studies where salmon were fed diets containing plant-based proteins. Condition of the salmon was increased in plant-based protein diets in one randomised, replicated, controlled study but reduced in two other replicated studies."

query: What does the evidence say about using probiotics, immunostimulants, or specific training to improve salmon survival against diseases?
relevant_summary: A replicated study in Scotland reported increased survival in salmon fed a probiotic before exposure to four disease-causing bacteria over 28 days compared with controls (732). A replicated, controlled study in Norway found salmon fed a diet with 28% plant-based protein had 28% fewer lice infections than controls, and adding beta-glucans decreased lice infection levels by a further 28%; mannan oligosaccharides also improved gut function by preventing soybean-induced enteritis (732). A randomized, replicated, controlled study in Norway found salmon that underwent aerobic training had higher survival when exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis, with interval training more effective than continuous training (740).

query: Based on studies in Australia, which husbandry practices have shown mixed or limited success in managing diseases and environmental impacts from salmon farming?
relevant_summary: Freshwater bathing showed mixed results for managing amoebic gill disease in Australia: one study found reduced amoebae on gills for up to 10 days after bathing, while a replicated, controlled study found similar amoebae levels in treated and untreated salmon [739]. Fallowing aimed at reducing parasites/disease showed limited success in Australia, with one study finding no difference in mortality from amoebic gill disease in cages where fallowing had been used [1026].
